body:
Wrote my own java version of zdump that can zdump the java timezone data and the jodatime timezone data (actually can host the command line zdump too).

So, here are the zdumps for Africa/Cairo.   The last one is JodaTime.

```
Transitions in zone Africa/Cairo from year 2014 upto year 2016 using zdump (OS)
zdump -v -c 2014,2016 Africa/Cairo | grep -v NULL
Africa/Cairo  Thu May 15 21:59:59 2014 UT = Thu May 15 23:59:59 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu May 15 22:00:00 2014 UT = Fri May 16 01:00:00 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jun 26 20:59:59 2014 UT = Thu Jun 26 23:59:59 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jun 26 21:00:00 2014 UT = Thu Jun 26 23:00:00 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jul 31 21:59:59 2014 UT = Thu Jul 31 23:59:59 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jul 31 22:00:00 2014 UT = Fri Aug  1 01:00:00 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 25 20:59:59 2014 UT = Thu Sep 25 23:59:59 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 25 21:00:00 2014 UT = Thu Sep 25 23:00:00 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Apr 23 21:59:59 2015 UT = Thu Apr 23 23:59:59 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Apr 23 22:00:00 2015 UT = Fri Apr 24 01:00:00 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jun 11 20:59:59 2015 UT = Thu Jun 11 23:59:59 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jun 11 21:00:00 2015 UT = Thu Jun 11 23:00:00 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jul 23 21:59:59 2015 UT = Thu Jul 23 23:59:59 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jul 23 22:00:00 2015 UT = Fri Jul 24 01:00:00 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 24 20:59:59 2015 UT = Thu Sep 24 23:59:59 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 24 21:00:00 2015 UT = Thu Sep 24 23:00:00 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200

Transitions in zone Africa/Cairo from year 2014 upto year 2016 using JVM (GregorianCalendar)
Africa/Cairo  Thu May 15 21:59:59 2014 UT = Thu May 15 23:59:59 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu May 15 22:00:00 2014 UT = Fri May 16 01:00:00 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jun 26 20:59:59 2014 UT = Thu Jun 26 23:59:59 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jun 26 21:00:00 2014 UT = Thu Jun 26 23:00:00 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jul 31 21:59:59 2014 UT = Thu Jul 31 23:59:59 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jul 31 22:00:00 2014 UT = Fri Aug  1 01:00:00 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 25 20:59:59 2014 UT = Thu Sep 25 23:59:59 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 25 21:00:00 2014 UT = Thu Sep 25 23:00:00 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Apr 23 21:59:59 2015 UT = Thu Apr 23 23:59:59 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Apr 23 22:00:00 2015 UT = Fri Apr 24 01:00:00 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800

Africa/Cairo  Thu Jul 23 21:59:59 2015 UT = Thu Jul 23 23:59:59 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Jul 23 22:00:00 2015 UT = Fri Jul 24 01:00:00 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 24 20:59:59 2015 UT = Thu Sep 24 23:59:59 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 24 21:00:00 2015 UT = Thu Sep 24 23:00:00 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200

Transitions in zone Africa/Cairo from year 2014 upto year 2016 using JodaTime (DateTime)
Africa/Cairo  Sun May 18 21:59:59 2014 UT = Sun May 18 23:59:59 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Sun May 18 22:00:00 2014 UT = Mon May 19 01:00:00 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Sun Jun 29 20:59:59 2014 UT = Sun Jun 29 23:59:59 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Sun Jun 29 21:00:00 2014 UT = Sun Jun 29 23:00:00 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Sun Aug  3 21:59:59 2014 UT = Sun Aug  3 23:59:59 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Sun Aug  3 22:00:00 2014 UT = Mon Aug  4 01:00:00 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 25 20:59:59 2014 UT = Thu Sep 25 23:59:59 2014 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 25 21:00:00 2014 UT = Thu Sep 25 23:00:00 2014 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Apr 23 21:59:59 2015 UT = Thu Apr 23 23:59:59 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Thu Apr 23 22:00:00 2015 UT = Fri Apr 24 01:00:00 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Sun Jun 14 20:59:59 2015 UT = Sun Jun 14 23:59:59 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Sun Jun 14 21:00:00 2015 UT = Sun Jun 14 23:00:00 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Sun Jul 26 21:59:59 2015 UT = Sun Jul 26 23:59:59 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
Africa/Cairo  Sun Jul 26 22:00:00 2015 UT = Mon Jul 27 01:00:00 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 24 20:59:59 2015 UT = Thu Sep 24 23:59:59 2015 EEST isdst=1 gmtoff=10800
Africa/Cairo  Thu Sep 24 21:00:00 2015 UT = Thu Sep 24 23:00:00 2015 EET isdst=0 gmtoff=7200
```

That last section shows that JodaTime really does not do Africa/Cairo well..
To set your expectations, I don't have much time to work on Joda-Time ATM, so cannot say when I could look at this (or the other two). If you want to have a go and submit a pull request, feel free.

Fair enough....  Likewise regarding time, but will see if I can fix.

On 17 September 2014 00:44, Stephen Colebourne notifications@github.com
wrote:

> To set your expectations, I don't have much time to work on Joda-Time ATM,
> so cannot say when I could look at this (or the other two). If you want to
> have a go and submit a pull request, feel free.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/JodaOrg/joda-time/issues/173#issuecomment-55736352.

I just came across the same issue. Its especially annoying because now the first three days after Egypt started their DST change (after three years without DST) are localized incorrectly (16-may-2014, 17-may-2014, 18-may-2014 in egypt). These rules were introduced with tzdata2014c.

More information about this topic:
http://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/egypt-reintroduces-dst-2014.html
http://www.timeanddate.com/time/change/egypt/cairo?year=2014

After a quick debug I could not figure out the cause of this issue, but I would be interested in a solution as well.

issue.title: Don't advance to dayOfWeek if it is 0

repository.name: joda-time
repository.description: Joda-Time is the widely used replacement for the Java date and time classes prior to Java SE 8.

issue.body:
If 24:00 is used with a specific day, it will advance to next Monday, since advance is set to true and dayOfWeek is updated to 1.

To fix #173:
1, don't set advance to true if dayOfWeek is 0.
2, don't update dayOfWeek if it is 0.

body:
So,  Asia/Amman also had this issue.    

Have also fixed in my fork...   In my solution, I spilt into separate flows as rather than repeating the same inline condition on multiple lines....   However, I had to comment out one of the unit tests but did do a zdump compare for a corresponding real world case for that failing test....  

Will also issue pull and let upstream decide on best approach.

zdump comparising between Calendar and DateTime transitions with both patched to Olson 2014g

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/lordbuddha/bits/master/zdump-diff-all-1970-2020-Olson2014g.txt

Ahh, I see Africa/Cairo is wrong again....  Will retry with longhua suggestion tomorrow.

issue.title: Don't advance to dayOfWeek if it is 0

repository.name: joda-time
repository.description: Joda-Time is the widely used replacement for the Java date and time classes prior to Java SE 8.

issue.body:
If 24:00 is used with a specific day, it will advance to next Monday, since advance is set to true and dayOfWeek is updated to 1.

To fix #173:
1, don't set advance to true if dayOfWeek is 0.
2, don't update dayOfWeek if it is 0.

body: Tested longhua's patch and it works for Africa/Cairo and Asia/Amman, does not break a unit test and adds a test of its own.
@lordbuddha Is it possible to publish your Java implementation of zdump that you used to compare transitions of Calendar vs DateTime?

Yes, when I can.  In a day-ish.    will just post the files up as have no
time for putting a project up properly.    The code has three zdump-ish
implementions.  1 for harnessing zdump (linux only), 1 for calendar and one
for datetime.

the side by side comparisons were just some little shell scripts....    The
whole thing is quite crude, but obviously useful.

issue.title: Timezone Africa/Cairo misbehaving in 2.4

repository.name: joda-time
repository.description: Joda-Time is the widely used replacement for the Java date and time classes prior to Java SE 8.

issue.title: The time of  'Asia/Dhaka' is wrong by using Joda 2.5

repository.name: joda-time
repository.description: Joda-Time is the widely used replacement for the Java date and time classes prior to Java SE 8.

issue.body:
Zone,            Joda,              Java,  Equal
Asia/Dacca,2014.11.21:13.29.47,2014.11.21:12.29.47,false
Asia/Dhaka,2014.11.21:13.29.47,2014.11.21:12.29.47,false
ROC,2014.11.21:14.29.47,2014.11.21:06.29.47,false

Here you can see, the time generated by Java is correct, but Joda is wrong in Asia/Dhaka, cannot solve it by using the latest timezone database.
